review.title: Mining Determinism in Human Strategic Behavior
review.abstract: This work lies in the fusion of experimental economics and data mining. It continues author's previous work on mining behaviour rules of human subjects from experimental data, where game-theoretic predictions partially fail to work. Game-theoretic predictions aka equilibria only tend to success with experienced subjects on specific games, what is rarely given. Apart from game theory, contemporary experimental economics offers a number of alternative models. In relevant literature, these models are always biased by psychological and near-psychological theories and are claimed to be proven by the data. This work introduces a data mining approach to the problem without using vast psychological background. Apart from determinism, no other biases are regarded. Two datasets from different human subject experiments are taken for evaluation. The first one is a repeated mixed strategy zero sum game and the second - repeated ultimatum game. As result, the way of mining deterministic regularities in human strategic behaviour is described and evaluated. As future work, the design of a new representation formalism is discussed.

metadata.title: Mining Determinism in Human Strategic Behavior

sections.text: ar Xiv: 121 1.23 99v1 [cs.GT] 1 1N ov2 01Keywords: game theory, psychology, data mining, artificial intelligence, domain-specific languages

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In fact, most of them are able to survive on their own, without being able to survive on their own.

sections.heading: 2 Related Work
sections.text: A very comprehensive collection of work in experimental psychology and economics on human behavior in general games can be found in [9]. This work inspired research in artificial intelligence [20], which led to the creation of a symbolic network of influence diagrams (NID) as representational formalism. NID is a formalism similar to the possible semantics of the Kripke models [21] and is a super-series of Bayesian games. The basic idea of NID is the modeling of human thought patterns in different SIs. Each node of an NID is a multi-agent influence diagram (MAID), which is a model of an agent's SI. MAID is an influence diagram (ID) in which each decision node is associated with an agent. ID is a Bayesian network (BN) in which one has common nodes, decision nodes, and use nodes. In summary, this approach assumes that human decision-making is possible in general games.

sections.heading: 3 Used Datasets
sections.text: The first set of data selected for our data mining approach was already mentioned in our previous paper [19]. It is the game RPS played over a computer network; this game is easy to explain and most people do not train to play it at expert level; it is symmetrical, zero-sum game and two players. The study was conducted on threads of 30 one-shot games. A player had a delay of 6 seconds for viewing each shot. If he did not respond, the last or default gesture was chosen. One thread lasted an average of 22.7 years and 7 of them were male. They had to play the thread twice against another tester, which represents an equal probability distribution between the three gestures. At least you can see these MSE.Ten computer science students were recruited. They were on average 22.7 years old and 7 of them were male. They had to play the thread twice against another tester. Between the two threads they each played different games.

sections.heading: 5 Empirical Results
sections.text: The first set of data is converted into a set of tuples, each of which consists of three separate previous gestures, three opposing previous gestures and their own next gestures. Therefore, each tupel has the length of 3 + 3 + 1 = 7. The simplification function is a window over three final rounds. There are 2187 possible tuples for RPS. Decisions made in the first three rounds of the game are not taken into account. Therefore, the size of the set is 540 tuples. The second set of data is also converted into a set of 371 tuples, in which each tupel includes the claimant's payout update, and the claimants Boolean repeat data. The implementations of classifiers provided by WEKA are used for cross-validating the two sets of tuples. For the first set, there are 45 classifiers available in the WEKA library that can handle multi-value nominal classes.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: Strategic behavior consists of observable actions, the origins of which are attempted to be understood as generally as possible. In summary, the SMO can find the most general deterministic hypothesis on regularities of human behavior in the scenarios studied. The correctness of such a hypothesis exceeds the figures reported in related work. SMO's hypothesis space is a complex function and can be used to formalize a formalism for describing game behavior.

referenceMentions.context: People can be regarded as rational, if they always make decisions, whose execution has according to their subjective estimation the most preferred consequences [2,3].
People can be regarded as rational, if they always make decisions, whose execution has according to their subjective estimation the most preferred consequences [2,3].
Further, game is a notion for the formal structure of a concrete SI [4].
However, there is at least one mixed strategies equilibrium (MSE) in finite games [5].
Some board games are even developed to train people, like Prussian army war game ”Kriegspiel Chess” [6] for officers.
We like it to train ourselves in order to perform better in games [7].
In most cases, common human behavior in games deviates from game-theoretic predictions [8,9].
In most cases, common human behavior in games deviates from game-theoretic predictions [8,9].
Although general human preferences are a subject of philosophical discussions [10], game theory assumes that they can be captured as required for modeling rationality.

Regarding people as rational agents is disputed at least in psychology, where even a scientifically accessible argumentation exposes the existence of stable and consistent human preferences as a myth [11].

527–530] Since the last six decades nevertheless, the common scientific standards for econometric experiments are that subjects’ preferences over outcomes can be insured by paying differing amounts of money [13].
The ability of modeling other people’s rationality and reasoning as well corresponds with the psychological term ”Theory of Mind” (ToM) [14], which lacks almost only in the cases of autism.
In Wason task at least, subjects’ reasoning does not match the researchers’ one [15].
Human rationality is not restricted to capability for science-grade logical reasoning – rational people may use no logic at all [16].
However, people also mistake seriously in the calculus of probabilities [17].
In mixed strategy games, the required sequence of random decisions can not be properly generated by people [18].
This work concentrates on human playing of general games and continues author’s previous work [19].
A very comprehensive gathering of works in experimental psychology and economics on human behavior in general games can be found in [9].
This work inspired research in artificial intelligence [20], which led to the creation of network of influence diagrams (NID) as a representation formalism.
NID is a formalism similar to the possible worlds semantics of Kripke models [21] and is a super-set of Bayesian games.
This formalism is already applied for modeling reciprocity in a repeated ultimatum game called ”Colored Trails” (CT) [22].
Another independent work is an application of a cognitive architecture from psychology to games [23].
A cognitive architecture is a formalism concerned to represent general human reasoning [24] in order to compare different models.
The first dataset chosen for our data mining approach has already been mentioned in our previous work [19].
The second dataset is the recorded responder behavior from the CT experiment [22].
Statistical analysis of the datasets from the previous chapter exposed that the human behavior observed in the experiments can not be explained using only game theory [1].
The shape of equilibrium deviations confirms the one reported in relevant literature [9].
” [23] In the addressed case of spectator prediction models, non-deterministic view can be regarded as too shallow, because deterministic models allow much more exact predictions.
Finding a hypothesis, which matches the regularity between input and output without a priori knowledge, is a typical problem called supervised learning [26].
Implementations of classifiers provided by WEKA [27] are used for the cross validation on the both sets of tuples.
Sequential minimal optimization (SMO) [28] showed 46.
48% prediction correctness, which is about 1% higher than the sophisticated non-deterministic model for RPS of Warglen [29].
One of this algorithms is based on decission tables [30].

15% of the CT dataset conforms the rule: ”If an acceptance does neither change your payoff nor improve the proposers payoff, then refuse!” This result overperforms clearly the 72% reported from the non-deterministic approach of Pfeffer [22].
